results.title: Pecheur D'islande = Iceland Fisherman (Cinemascope Print)
results.creator_credit: Pierre Schoendoerffer and Georges de Beauregard
results.brief_description:
Yann, a sailor, is in charge of the ‘Pecheur d’Islande’, a fishing boat said to be jinxed. The boat belongs to Mevel, a rich ship owner whose daughter, Gaud, is in love with Yann. After Gaud’s father becomes bankrupt, Gaud and Yann get married. But their happiness is short-lived. A week after their wedding, Yann goes back to sea while Gaud must struggle to adapt a life of endless waiting. ‘Pecheur d’Islande’ revealed to a vast audience the epic story of the fishing expeditions to the arctic seas.

Credits: Producer, Georges de Beauregard ; director, Pierre Schoendoerffer ; writers, Pierre Schoendoerffer, Andre Tabet ; photography ; Raoul Coutard ; music, Charles Aznavour.
Cast: Jean-Claude Pascal, Juliette Mayhiel, Charles Vanel, Georges Poujouly.

results.title: Ak: Akira Kurosawa
results.brief_description:
Chris Marker follows the arduous location shooting of ‘Ran’, profiling Kurosawa and his collaborators, examining the director’s techniques, and placing the film in context with his previous work.

Credits: Producer, Serge Silberman ; director, Chris Marker ; photography, Franz-Yves Marescot ; music, Toru Takemitsu.
results.description:

results.title: Biquefarre
results.creator_credit: Georges Rouquier, Bertrand van Effenterre, Marie-Francoise Mascaro and William Gilcher
results.brief_description:
Georges Rouquier revisits the characters of his 1938 ‘Biquefarre’ 35 year later. The family whose farm was wired for electricity in the first film are still on the family spread in 1983. The plot revolves around Raoul who decides to sell the farm to take up a job as gardener with the City of Toulouse. Though documentary in technique, the film is well planned and scripted, with its amateur cast convincingly mouthing the lines given them by Rouqier.

Credits: Producer, Bertrand van Effenterre, Marie-Francoise Mascaro, William Gilcher ; director, Georges Rouquier ; writers, Georges Rouquier, Maria Signorini ; photography, Andre Villard ; music, Yves Gilbert
Cast: Henri Rouquier, Maria Rouquier, Roger Malet, Roch Rouquier, Raymond Rouquier.

results.title: L'adolescente = the Adolescent
results.brief_description:
L’Adolescente’ was the second directorial stint for film star Jeanne Moreau. Marie, a twelve-year old girl, spends the long summer holiday in the country on the eve of WWII. Her interest for games with the village children is distracted by the presence of Alexandre, a young doctor.

Credits: Producer, Philippe Dussart ; director, Jeanne Moreau ; writers, Henriette Jelinek, Jeanne Moreau ; photography, Pierre Gautard ; music, Philippe Sarde.
Cast: Laetitia Chauveau, Simone Signoret, Edith Clever, Jacques Weber, Francis Huster, Jean-Francois Balmer, Michel Blanc, Hugues Quester, Jacques Rispal, Maurice Baquet, Roger Blin.

results.title: Le Miroir a Deux Faces = the Mirror Has Two Faces
results.brief_description:
A rather unambitious schoolmaster, living with his mother, marries a very plain woman. After six dreary years of marriage, the wife is transformed into a beauty by plastic surgery only to see her husband’s indifference turn into jealousy.

Credits: Producer, Alain Poire ; director, Andre Cayatte ; writers, Andre Cayatte, Gerard Oury, Denis Perret, Jean Meckert ; photography, Christian Matras ; music, Louiguy.
Cast: Michele Morgan, Bourvil, Ivan Desny, Elisabeth Manet, Sandra Milo, Sylvie, Jane Marken, Carette.

results.title: Danton
results.brief_description:
The clash between warmly idealistic Danton and the coldly pragmatic Robespierre over the way the French revolution should go. ‘Danton’, is a film of highly dramatic power, at once a mature study of the revolutionary mentality and an absorbing intellectual spectacle. Awards: Prix Louis Delluc 1982 ; French Academy of Cinema 1983 (Cesar): best director for Andrzej Wajda ; British Academy Awards 1983: best foreign film. The film’s power derives from a series of contrasts between Danton and Robespierre on the level of characterisation and staging as much as ideology. The conflict is most evident when the two men confront each other’s claustrophobic and enclosed spaces, particularly during the aborted supper in Danton’s private apartment. In such scenes the theatricality of the dialogue, rendered all the more artificial by the dubbing of Pszoniak, is at odds with Depardieu’s more relaxed and gestural performance, which recalls the more enigmatic power of the silent cinema. The political conflict between the two is underlined not just by the contrast in styles of performance, but also by Wajda’s mise en scene, so that Danton’s clothes and rooms are red, Robespierre’s blue. This simple colour scheme is complemented by the use of white, which symbolises revolutionary purity and completes the republican tricolour.” Reference: Guy Austin. ‘Contemporary French cinema: an introduction’. Manchester University Press, 1996.

Credits: Producer, Margaret Menegoz ; director, Andrzej Wajda ; writer, Jean-Claude Carriere ; photography, Igor luther ; music, Jean Podromides.
Cast: Gerard Depardieu, Wojtek Pszoniak, Patrice Chereau, Roger Planchon, Andrzej Seweryn, Angela Winkler, Jacques Villeret, Roland Blanche, Boguslaw Linda.

results.title: Paris Vu Par = Six in Paris
results.brief_description:
At a time when the New Wave had lost its initial momentum, Schroeder commissioned six ‘new’ directors - Douchet, Rouch, Pollet, Rohmer, Godard and Chabrol - to each produce a short film organised around daily life in a specific geographic locale in Paris. They were made on 16 mm. film (subsequently blown up to 35 mm.) both for low cost and to capture something of the raw documentary feel of television reportage. Rouch, for example, used ‘the ten minute take’ while cinema verite film maker Albert Maysles, the cameraman in Godard’s episode, filmed without much idea of what Godard and the actors had in mind. Best print: X0072.

Credits: (Saint Germain des Pres) Director, Jean Douchet ; photography, Nestor Almendros ; (Gare du Nord) director, script, Jean Rouch ; photography, Etienne Becker ; (Rue Saint Denis) director, script, Jean Daniel Pollet ; photography, Alain Levent ;

results.title: Les Cousins = the Cousins
results.creator_credit: Claude Chabrol, Paul Wagner and Ajym Films
results.brief_description:
Simple, good-hearted country cousin Charles comes to study at the Sorbonne in Paris where he stays at the luxury apartment of Paul, his cynical city cousin. Charles works hard but fails his exams, Paul doesn’t but passes and gets Charles’s girl. Chabrol’s second feature film re-unites Jean-Claude Brialy and Gerard Blain, the two lead actors from his debut feature, ‘Le Beau Serge’. Paul (Brialy) is a hedonistic and confident Parisian student living in his uncle’s fashionable inner city flat. He spends his time drinking, carousing, sleeping with a variety of female friends and playing the role of matchmaker for his friends, arranging trysts in an ongoing merry go round of bed partners. He is an emotionally remote and decadent man, adhering to a dubious moral code, who approaches his friends love lives with devilish detachment. Charles (Blain) is his naive country cousin, a dedicated student, who stays with Paul whilst studying for his law exams. When Charles is introduced to Paul’s swinging set, he instantaneously falls for Florence, a beautiful woman who is intrigued by Charles’ innocence. Paul is perturbed as he observes the attraction between the two and the respect that Charles displays for Florence. A clash is inevitable as the rivalry for Florences affection grows. The contrast between the two main characters morality is acute, especially in their attitudes toward women. A dramatic study of class conflict and personal responsibility ‘Les Cousins’ is a riveting and perverse study of decadent Parisian student life. The City of Lights is captured by Decae’s camera as if seen through the amazed eyes of Charles. The film won the Best Film award at the Berlin Film Festival in 1959. Also available on VHS.

Credits: Producer, Paul Wagner ; director, Claude Chabrol ; writers, Claude Chabrol, Paul Gegauff ; photography, Henri Decae ; music, Paul Misraki ; editing, Jacques Gaillard.
Cast: Gerard Blain, Jean-Claude Brialy, Juliette Mayniel, Claude Cerval, Genevieve Cluny, Guy Decomble, Stephane Audran.

results.title: Le Voyage du Pere = the Father's Trip
results.creator_credit: Denys de la Patelliere and Raymond Danon
results.brief_description:
At his wife’s request, Monsieur Quentin, leaves his farm to go to city in order to convince his daughter to attend a family gathering. Once in town, he discovers that his daughter has become a prostitute.

Credits: Producer, Raymond Danon ; director, Denys de la Patelliere ; writers, Denys de la Patelliere, Pascal Jardin ; photography, Jean Tournier ; music, Georges Garvarentz.
Cast: Fernandel, Philippe Noiret, Lilli Palmer, Michel Auclair, Laurent Terzieff, Madeleine Robinson, Rosy Varte.

results.title: Les Creatures = the Creatures
results.creator_credit: Agnes Varda, Mag Bodard and Philippe Dussart
results.brief_description:
A novelist and his pregnant wife go on holidays after he is horribly scarred during an automobile accident. He uses the time to complete his new novel and the local residents become models for his characters.

Credits: Producers, Mag Bodard, Philippe Dussart ; director, Agnes Varda ; writer, Agnes Varda ; photography, Willy Kurant, William Lubtchansky ; music, Pierre Barbaud.
Cast: Michel Piccoli, Catherine Deneuve, Eva Dahlbeck, Britta Patterson, Jacques Charrier, Lucien Bodard, Ursula Kubler, Nino Castelnuovo.
